STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 13, 2023
Kimberly Noelle Bair
ALLEGAN COUNTY DHHS
3255 122ND AVE,
ALLEGAN, MI, 49010-9590
Re: License #: CP030200937
Dear Kimberly Noelle Bair:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
10/9-1012/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
(3)The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a)A written evaluation of a staff member’s performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months
after the member assumes his or her current
responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a written
evaluation must be conducted every 12 months.
1 of 13 employee files reviewed contained an annual performance evaluation that
was not completed timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection Report 10/22/2021, CAP Approved 11/15/2021
FOM 722-06B F AMILY TEAM MEETING
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case
Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan
2

due date. Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three
business days prior to a planned change of placement or
no later than three business days after an unplanned
placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case
closure date or one business day after unplanned court
ordered dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, is used to capture family demographics, FTM
logistical information, needs, strengths, action steps,
safety concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the FTM.
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business
days of the FTM.
1 of 6 open files of youth in foster care placements was missing one FTM required
for service plan development.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection Report 10/22/2021, CAP Approved 11/15/2021
FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND
S IGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker
• Supervisor
• Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are
placed apart
• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court-ordered caregivers.
3

Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must
check yes or no for the following when signing the
treatment plan:
• I have participated in the development of the
Case Service Plan and the Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
• I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan.
• I have been provided a copy of the Case Service
Plan and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to
review, and I will have the opportunity to express
my disagreement with the Case Service Plan and
Parent Agency Treatment Plan when the
information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to
sign the treatment plan, the caseworker must identify,
and document actions needed to secure the parent’s
and/or youth’s participation in service planning and
compliance with the treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the
electronic case record within 30 days of the report date.
2 of 6 open files of youth in foster care placements did not meet all PATP signature
requirements. One file contained one PATP that did not have the worker and
supervisor signatures and one PATP that did not have the supervisor signature.
Both of these PATPs were signed by the parents. The other file contained one
PATP signed by the parent outside of the 30 day timeframe. The PATPs in violation
represented 3 of 16 PATPs reviewed.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection Report 10/22/2021, CAP Approved 11/15/2021
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• While it is documented in CWLM and special evaluation reports that the 45-day
letter was sent, when applicable, the letter should be uploaded to verify it
contains the rule required information.
• Be sure to update, generate and save medical passports quarterly, even when
not obtaining signatures quarterly. If the only page being uploaded is the
signature page, generating and saving verifies that an updated medical passport
is being signed.
• Ensure foster parents are dating their signatures.
4

V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Workers should be utilizing a copy of the PATP that is signed by the worker and
supervisor when asking caregivers, parents, and youth to sign the document.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The one
CAP submitted by the agency was in respnse to the 10/10/2023 licensing renewal
inspection report and was approved on 10/28/2023. That CAP addressed 7
violations, none of which were repeated during this inspection. The agency has
corrected their non-compliances in all of the areas addressed in that CAP. Of the
three violations established during this inspection, all were also found in 2021;
however, two of those violations were isolated incidents during this inspection. The
agency has seen a reduction in overall violations as well as a reduction in
individual instances of violation over the past two years.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency Director, who is the assigned chief administrator, is currently on leave.
The agency Program Manager is currently acting as Director as well as Program
Manager and completed the Chief Administrator assessment. He identified several
areas in which prior CAP implementation has improved compliance. He did
identify a barrier with compliance attributed to staff performance that required
leadership to provide additional coaching and oversight as well as disciplinary
action as staff needed guidance regarding the difference between conducting a
home visit with the youth and foster parents every calendar month as opposed to
every 30 days.
Financial Overview
No applicable.
Staff and Youth Interviews
The staff interviewed all reported feeling supported by co-workers and
management and did not express any concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency appears to have adequate space and equipment to perform the
required job functions. The CHRI, adoption, and case files are stored within
5

lockable cabinets to prevent unauthorized access and destruction. The files are all
maintained within the office, which can only be accessed through two locked
doors. Any non-employees who enter the office must be escorted by an employee,
further preventing any unauthorized individuals from having access to confidential
files that may be in use by staff out of their stored locations.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Analyst identified 3 safety concerns as follows:
Safety Alert 1: Relative home had a pool and no safety alarms or rescue
equipment.
Resolution: The agency provided the family with door alarms and rescue
equipment. The agency also provided DCWL with the pool safety plan which had
been put into place upon placement of the youth.
Safety Alert 2: Relative caregiver refused to meet with the DCWL Analyst
Resolution: The agency visited the home on 8/7/2023 and verified safety of the
youths and the home.
Safety Alert 3: Relative home had a pool without filtration, a barrier, door alarms, or
rescue equipment.
Resolution: The agency provided photographs of the pool taken down as well as a
written agreement by the relative to sign a safety plan if the pool is to be put back
up.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
October 12, 2023
________________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
